Definition: If you find that the input comment has pornographic materials and activities that offend the public's sense of decency, then classify it as obscene else classify it as non-obscene.

In the autumn of 1971 I was standing on a dock in northern Manitoba ... a newly-minted school-teacher attending an orientation session before heading still further north. A young native guy walks out along the dock and joins me at the end. A beautiful evening. Silence. Maybe geese overhead ... 

He speaks ... not to me ... but out ... clearly ... onto the big calm lake.

"There is an old legend from my people. <pause> If a hunter makes a very strong bow ... and goes out onto the land and shoots an arrow straight up into the sky ... <pause again> it will strike a large airplane. And on that airplane there will be at least one Indian going to a conference."

Buddy turned to me, smiled mischievously.

You can't "make-up" this shit.

Comment: From very young ages, my 4 kids had first hand visuals of the mortality and devastating trauma caused by guns on game animals. The cute bunny, deer, bear, etc. laying lifeless with a bloody hole in it. And it didn't get up to star in the next movie. Still, to the chagrin of my peers, I never let them point toy guns (or even their fingers) at a human and say "POW!" No squirt gun fights, playing 'Army', 'Cops and Robbers', 'Cowboys and Indians' or Grand Theft Auto type video games (These came out later and as "adults" they played them anyway...). And I screened (to the best of my ability) their intake of movies and TV. Perhaps I was viewed as a hard ass, but, I know first hand that it sucks to be shot. Yet, guns have always been an important tool in my life and I'm not one to throw out a hammer over a black thumbnail. I've kept them handy and I've kept them loaded. If you haven't taken the time to discipline your children before getting a gun, maybe you should get a baseball bat instead.

With population growth, urbanization and industrialization in, as you point out, especially China and India, our "carbon footprint" just keeps growing.  The best we can do is to try to "slow it down."  Unless there's a concerted and coordinated worldwide commitment to address all the factors (including population growth), we're doomed to ever-increasing and ever-accelerating warming.

It won't be pretty.   Regards, Gary

The idea is to connect the high tech sector of waterloo, with that of toronto... but to also connect the more manufacturing and rising tech sector of london. We all know the fucking via train sucks from london to toronto. It takes forever, is probably comparable to flying in price, and you can drive there faster. This is a project that could potentially revitalize the niagara peninsula and take a lot of traffic off the 401.

Comment: Outsider:  It's tough to rewrite history, but I'll give you credit for trying.  The Southern economy was premised on slavery and the leaders perceived, probably correctly, that the end of slavery would cause a tremendous upheavel in Southern life...both culturally and economically.  Those leaders also perceived (again, likely very correctly) that, with the election fo Abraham Lincoln and the ever-growing power of the Abolitionist movement, slavery in the U.S. was coming to an end....and likely in the near future.  Rather than seek to negotiate as favorable a transition as possible, likely including compensation for emancipated slaves, the South chose to secede.  It's no surprise that most the young men in the South chose to support secession. They were raised in the South and slavery was part of the values system of their lives.  ....and, yes, those damn Yankees were going to end slavery.  Gary Crum

Comment: CRA does not like to publicize it much but ID theft has been a growing problem for years. People file a phony tax return in your name very early on in the tax filing season, collect a refund, and that leaves you with sorting out the details with CRA.  The agency doesn't really care, though, because the money that they send you isn't theirs, it belongs to the government. I mean, it's not part of their budget. Dedicating a group to fighting ID fraud and making changes to their computer systems to make it harder for people to do this has been 'under consideration' for many years. The problem is that would cost THEM money (from their budget) to implement, and the money saved isn't 'theirs'.  The changes would probably save the government, overall, a hundred or more dollars for every dollar spent, but that's not how departments look at things. Until the government orders them to do something about it they won't.

No sale if taxes paid aren't commensurate with the RE purchase price.

Comment: Misprision of felony was abolished in most English speaking countries as part of a reform to overcome the problems created by the distinction between felonies and misdemeanours. Very few jurisdictions created a statutory form. It is true that it appears in statutory form in the United States Code, but it has been narrowly interpreted to mean that simply saying nothing is not of itself a crime. It requires some form of active concealment. Canada and New Zealand do not have it. The UK didn't have it in 2014, but Ireland has it in relation to child sexual abuse sincev2012, and Victoria did the same in 2014. Some countries in the continental legal system have an equivalent,  like France and Colombia, but Germany and Holland do not. Most countries have some kind of welfare reporting for children, but in many jurisdictions clergy are not mandatory reporters

Comment: After 65 years in Alaska, I never take the beauty for granted. I love sharing the beauty with visitors, which I just spent three weeks doing. Visiting places I've been countless times; I never tire of having my breath taken away with the views both large and small. Even right here in Anchorage, with five mountain ranges around us, the quality of the light in all its mutations throughout the seasons, and the changes in weather fills me with awe daily. Recently standing at the end of Turnagain Arm and thinking of the hundreds of time I had taken in that view, I was moved to tears at the natural beauty that is my home. Sitting at a red light, almost anywhere in Anchorage, I see people looking completely oblivious to their surroundings. All you have to do is look up-look at the mountains, the clouds, the view!  I know all of the places that the roads rise up and give you a far off view of the Alaska Range, the Aleutians, the Talkeetnas; and of course, the ever present Chugach. Never dull.

Comment: The best monthly measure of UK inflation for central bank purposes now available is likely the RPI excluding mortgage interest payments and council tax adjusted for the formula affect, which approximates a monthly UK HICP with an OOH(NA) component. It went from 3.1% in April and May to 3.0% in June. And it is still downward biased, as it excludes stamp duty, which should have been added to the RPI measure. Alan Clarke spoke of UK inflation exceeding the 3% upper bound later this year. Properly measured, UK inflation has been above 3% from April forward.

Comment: You mean the same reason that TVs and cars and haircuts and oil changes are "so expensive"?  No, for-profit is not what makes something expensive.  Nearly all products and services in our system are for-profit yet TVs aren't $5000 and haircuts aren't $200.

What makes things way more expensive than they should be is when the free market checks and balances are destroyed, like they mostly have been in healthcare (thanks mostly to government interference).  We need to restore real choice and real competition to the system, and minimize 3rd party payment.  When other people's money is paying for something, costs and prices soar.

Comment: Lots of kids whose parents are in chaos are raised by stable relatives, such as grandparents.  

With my own 8 year old, my policy is to host the first playdate, then make sure I do the dropoff a little earlier than arranged to ensure that I have time to chat with the parent and, maybe, get myself invited into their house.  I also make sure I serve the kid a snack or meal, then take that opportunity to gently chat them up (what kind of snack do you normally get after school?  What's your favourite thing to do at home?  Do you watch much TV?)   The kid won't really know what you're doing, but you should be able to get a basic sense of their house rules and, by extension, how responsible the caregivers are.  Experienced grandparents are probably better than half the first-time parents in your kid's school anyway!

Comment: Not surprised, Calgary house prices have been outpaced by inflation over the last ten years.  There have been minor bumps and valleys, but on the whole property values have been falling (taking inflation into account).  I bought my house ten years ago for 470k, this year it was evaluated at 490k.  If it had followed 2% inflation it would be 572k.

Before anyone claims this was a bad investment, remember that despite what Kevin O'Leary says,  the rate-of-return calculation for a house investment where you live is not just your rate of return on the money you put in.  You are also putting equity down instead of paying rent.

Comment: This is an issue of consent, which essentially means the ability of someone to agree to take part in something. If I show up to work, completely intoxicated, and get fired as a result, I have no legal leg to stand on. If I kill someone while I am driving, intoxicated, the law will not care that I was unable to clearly think about what I was doing. So, why is it an issue when someone engages in sexual activity while intoxicated? When I was in university, I had sex while I was intoxicated. As individuals, we are all responsible for what we put into our bodies. The minute we decide to consume alcohol (or narcotics)  we are responsible for what we do while we are under the influence. And, before the bashing starts, I am only talking about the issue of consent while intoxicated. I am not debating the criminality of sexual assault, rape or any other sex-related crimes. Clearly, those who commit such crimes, should be held accountable for their actions and punished accordingly.

Comment: I think that there are a few more consequential differences. One can easily make the case that this is the most divided the US has been since the 1960s. Also, one can see the roots of the current situation in decisions made at that time. Trump is a natural culmination of many Republican racial policies; he is different because he said openly what the Republicans had been saying with dog whistles since Nixon introduced the Southern strategy. The Trump situation also seems to be a very deliberate effort to roll back many of the gains made by minorities over the past 40 years. One way in which Trump is absolutely unique is that he has put forward a foreign policy that undermines most of the post-WWII consensus in US politics. Whether or not he will act on this remains to be seen,  but his anti-free trade, leadership by extortion message is a marked departure and has many American allies reconsidering their reliance on the US.

Comment: Canadians are better at whining on and on about America than we are at just about anything, except for maybe WInter Olympics and Hockey.

And part of our whining on and on about America is that whenever the Americans make a movie about Canadian material (example: Argo, about the Iran hostage events, and Superbad, based on school graduation in BC), we sit around and pout and whimper and whine for weeks about how hard done-by we are for not getting better exposure in the movie narrative.

And we nurse our wounds for months, years, until the next example happens, and we again take offense at the dastardly Americans.

A useless and maladaptive behavior, that whining. It fills the void that should be filled with popular made-in-Canada movies that we never make. We are like the neighbourhood loser who always spouts off about how he should have been made captain of the high school football team, a story he bitterly tells for seven decades before dying with a bitter expression on hise face.

Comment: I will leave aside a discussion of O'Leary's success, or lack thereof, in business for the moment.  The notion that success in business is a necessary and sufficient condition for success as Prime Minister is ludicrous, if only because there is far more to a country and society than the economy.  It is a critical component as the engine that generates the wealth that is the source of revenue for public activities, but it is only one facet of a country.  If one could run a government as a company, with the focus only on the bottom line, then it would be a business.  Government takes on those activities that the private sector is incapable of assuming because the considerations go beyond simple profit and loss.

To the members of the Conservative Party, please provide Canadians with a viable choice for Prime Minister, not some pompous self-aggrandizing blowhard with no compassion for the life the common man or woman.

Comment: The author took the wrong takeaway.  Its not that everyone hates the idea of waiting until 70 on principle.  It is that he wrote a flawed and incomplete article advocating it, which did disservice to his overall argument.   

Even now, he suddenly has dropped their savings (saying that they have more than enough even under suboptimal) before announcing they'd run out of money at 85 without waiting for CPP.

It is stuff like this that make it feel like a cherry picked and oversimplified argument.  A specific income goal sweet spot  just over their age 70 CPP+OAS, savings in a window of 6-8 times the income goal.

It is very likely that for this specific example, even if properly presented, waiting for CPP is best. They have relatively low savings, so hedging against longevity makes sense.  But every example is different.   

Walking people through how to figure out how the math works for them would seem a much more useful article than constructing an example that simply may not apply.

Comment: I rarely carry cash anymore, much less coins, but I found out that this can be a bad thing occasionally.  I recently had to go to the Fasi Building and parked in the underground structure where all parking is metered.  The meters take cards, so I stuck my card in but for whatever reason, it was denying the card.  It might have been just that meter, but parking was tight that day, and I couldn't just move stalls.  I had no coins on me.  Thankfully, another person was coming to his car, so I asked if he had coins to trade for bills and luckily, he did.  Funny thing was, I went to the security office close by, and they don't give change.  Their suggestion was to go into the building where they have a convenience store, purchase something (after waiting in line for ID check, then waiting in line again to exit), then get change....assuming that no one will come by to ticket my car for an expired meter in the mean time.  Lesson learned:  carry 8-12 quarters in the car at all times!

One way to address it is to have a yearly income requirement, a cut-off, commensurate with the income level that would be needed for a worker to buy a house. In other words, the full-time worker couple of lawyer plus doctor would pass the cut-off level, but the $10,000 a year part timer student would not.

In a sense, that barrier would be a bit comparable (though different from) the barrier faced when a family approaches a bank for a mortgage, the lower-wage family being refused a mortgage on the expensive house and the higher income family being granted one.

Comment: The state sells land all the time.  It's an ongoing process, but it's not a remedy.  The budget gap is $2.4Billion.  The state couldn't sell enough land at fair market value to close a $2.4B gap one year, let alone every year.  Go to the Alaska Department of Revenue website and find the Revenue Sources Book, which will show income from land sales.  Look at the RSBs for, say, the past five years to get an average of revenue from land sales.  Even if you could double the sales--which you couldn't--the revenue from land sales would still be woefully insufficient to close the budget gap.  Nobody wants to buy land that isn't surveyed, so the state would have to pay for that, and the state has other staff to manage sales so they're fair and legal.  Don't assume the state isn't constantly earnestly endeavoring to make money off state resources, incl. raw land (as well as oil, minerals, timber, water).  The state IS trying to make money, always has been.  No easy "remedy" has been overlooked.

Comment: Margaret, it's pretty hard to argue against doing "something different" when "something" remains undefined.  Have you any suggestions?

I am heartened by the British resolve in both London and Manchester to carry on as normally as possible in the face of tragedy -- and sickened by Corbyn making political hay out of it.  He has spoken out against increased surveillance in the past, making him a hypocrite as well as an opportunist.

Terrorism is notoriously difficult to stop.  The cells are loosely organized, if at all, and there is usually little warning that a tragedy is in the works.  

Heightened vigilance is, of course, required.  So is prosecution to the full extent of the law for those found plotting attacks.  I don't think even civil libertarians would object to a closer than usual eye on any group known to be hostile to the status quo.

But we must never give in to the temptation to become a police state, intern people based on faith, or act outside of the law.

Comment: I'd been following details of this fire on the UK Telegraph and BBC News and heard accounts of residents who were woken by the sound of neighbors pounding on their doors or the commotion of fire trucks and sirens from outside.   One resident was even on the phone with her friend and was told by her friend that her building was on fire and she needed to get out.   Were there even fire alarms?!!?  This whole tragic fiasco makes one wonder what year London is living in -- 1905?

If anything good comes out of this it will be a grave reminder of just how important strong fire and building codes are, along with strong enforcement of those codes.   The U.S. had its very own Cocoanut Grove fire in Boston in 1942 in which 492 people lost their lives due to terrible fire safety in the nightclub.   That was a wake up call for us.  Unfortunately, people tend to forget these tragedies and safety can be replaced by cost-saving measures and cutting corners...

Comment: Night Owl, I'm not trying to pick a fight with or belittle you over this harboring a fugitive business--I like your commenting style, even if I might disagree with you. Where you and the others are going wrong on this harboring business and the reading of the law is in comprehending the meaning of the law. The law is arcane and abstruse, often to society's detriment. Specifically, the notion of harboring entails the act of concealment, but the church has made no attempt to conceal her whereabouts. In fact, her whereabouts is front page news. Therefore, the church is not "harboring" in contravention of the law. Ask yourself why juries are given instructions in the law, why a court just ruled Trumps travel ban illegal, and why judgments and convictions are sometimes overturned. The law is not always so clear.

Comment: I think the scope and definition of "medically necessary" in 1958/1966 vs 2017 is hard to fathom.

A lot of medical care at this time would be hospital-based.  Outpatient medicine would really be limited to vaccinations, routine physicals and house-calls.  Chronic disease management didn't really exist at this time.

Now, anything besides cosmetic surgery is considered to be "medically necessary" no matter the acuity or how benign it is.
Doctors' days are spent doing a lot of social work, mental health care, addictions, managing lifestyle diseases like diabetes and hypertension and managing the elderly and chronic pain.

It's the chasm between having collision insurance in case of an accident vs. having your insurance company involved in getting the oil changed on your car.

Comment: So many liberals are members of SEIU or AFSCME where being fired for not working is almost impossible that they don't understand the Federal Laws which prohibit striking by certain groups of employees even if they are members of a union.  

The Railway Labor Act bans strikes by United States airline and railroad employees except in narrowly defined circumstances. The National Labor Relations Act generally permits strikes, but  can enjoin strikes in industries in which a strike would create a national emergency. The federal government most recently invoked  to obtain an injunction requiring the International Longshore and Warehouse Union return to work in 2002.

Postal workers involved in 1978 wildcat strikes in Jersey City, Kearny, New Jersey, San Francisco, and Washington, D.C. were fired under the presidency of Jimmy Carter.

Many States, like New York, prohibit police officer and firemen strikes.

Comment: Here in Richmond BC (population 220,000), we have already lost one of our local newspapers.  The remaining paper, the Richmond News, is the only source of information specific to our city, and the primary way of holding the City and politicians to account.

Everything from land use contracts, to development, to zoning, overseas junkets to  "sister  cities", development variance permits,  upcoming festivals and special events.  And of course a place for citizens to sound off and hold politicians feet to the fire.

The loss of this paper would go a long way to stopper information (and dissent). And sadly, no doubt some would see this as a good thing.

It's viability now is reliant on advertising, especially as a wrap for flyers.  I would hope that the paper makes enough money to keep operating.  

"You don't know what you've got 'til it's gone."

Public Health Reports,  Vol. 125, No. 5, 647-54.
.
4. Researchers estimated that in 2003 Colorado saved nearly $149 million in unnecessary treatment costs by fluoridating public water supplies‚Äîaverage savings of roughly $61 per person.

------O‚ÄôConnell J.M. et al., ‚ÄúCosts and savings associated with community water fluoridation programs in Colorado,‚Äù
Preventing Chronic Disease (November 2005), accessed on

to be cont....
.
Steven D. Slott, DDS

Comment: "So , the oil companies should be responsible for fixing the potholes and if there are not then that is classified as a subsidy ..."

.
Why do we subsidize one form of transportation - to the hilt - but not the other?
.
In the 1950's and 1960's, the public subsidies of highways were so extreme they very nearly bankrupted the entire railroad system in North America.  That occurred notwithstanding that the railroads are roughly 10 times as energy efficient as highway transport trailers, and notwithstanding that there were some core businesses that could not be shifted to the highways.
.

.
It might be different if road repairs were paid by road tolls, but they are not.  Highway expenditures come directly out of general revenues.

Once we become a society with the attitude that it's "too bad for you," we are done.

Comment: Slate did a story a few years back, and others have done similar ones, that essentially show that surveys like this one are essentially worthless. In the US less than 10% will respond. The number goes up if people are offered something free for taking the survey. The results of the survey swing wildly depending on what time of day the pollster calls. Pew, also in the US, did a survey as part of a program to check how accurate they were, where they selected several thousand people, randomly split the group into two, then asked the people essentially the same question but worded  differently and got different results. The result was that pollsters can get any result they or their clients want.

Most of this is common sense.

Comment: Muckamuck, I'm no journalist, but I helped create the system, so I'll try to explain! 

Each time a person comments, they must rate 3 comments from others‚Äîon each one, they first rate for quality, and then for civility. When you're still new, we ask you to also rate *your own* comment, and give you a chance to edit it before submitting (in case you have second thoughts).

Your comment is then reviewed by others in the same way. The number of people who review your comment varies, depending on what our backend algorithms "learn" from the initial reviews of it, and what they "learn" about how you reviewed the comments of others. The comment is then either published or withheld. I can't get much further into it (that's a lot of our "secret sauce"!), but I can say: we've worked hard to prevent cheating and bias.

Comment: I don't personally know what obligations the State was not meeting, or what amount is correct. That's what the plaintiffs' suit is all about--to get an objective determination of the amount from the court, since in the plaintiffs' view the State has been low-balling the figure. While it is true that the problem should have been corrected without litigation, by agreeing to settle the case, the State was implicitly admitting that it would lose if it forced the plaintiffs to go to trial. Since Rep. Luke has rejected the settlement to which the State agreed, she has forced the court to decide the issue, and the cost (including the attorneys fees that the State will be obligated to pay in full if it loses at trial, which is likely) will very likely be substantially higher than the figure set forth in the settlement. Thanks, Rep. Luke--your fit of pique is going to cost us big time.

Comment: Personally, I question using a late first round picks on QB's..it seems that after the first 1-2 QB's are taken and usually within the the first 12 picks, you might as well use a later pick in rounds 2-4 for one strictly from a value standpoint. If a guy doesn't have the talent as a first rounder not to start sometime that first season and definitely by year two, then its probably a wasted 1st round pick. 

If Paxton was a 4th rounder, would the expectations be as high? If he doesn't have it, you can cut the player without much backlash. Looking at the last 10 years of late first round picks...very few really did much...Lynch, Manziel, Weedon, Tebow, Freeman, Brady Quinn and Bridgewater...the only true success stories was Flacco at #18 and maybe Bridgewater (although a small time frame due to injury) in the last 10 drafts. It's such a hit or miss with QB's after the first few picks in each draft.

Comment: Benefits of global warming may not be in the headlines because there's evidence that few will happen.  E.g., the Hoover Institute has said that crops will grow faster, bigger, and better.  But it turns out that (a) more droughts and floods are already diminishing crops in current "breadbasket" areas, and (b) the mix of crucial components in (say) grains of wheat is inferior at higher temperatures.  As for Alaska, the boreal forest/shrub ecosystem is already trending towards grassland, due to more fires, insects, and disease (think fewer moose), and many salmon streams have become too warm to support young fish.

Comment: The honourable minister's weak math and logic skills, and disingenuous arguments, as evidenced in this article, were a more likely driver of her bottom 10% pay than any alleged systemic issues.

Of the 1880 regular CRC appointments, women represent just under 31% of the total applicants and hold slightly more than 28% of the Chairs, representing at most an 8.5% difference between the expected allocation and the actual.

Not nearly as dire as the inveigled 'gap' between the 31% actual and ~50% female population at large.

Moreover, the CRC's own rules were actually punitive to women by excluding/restricting applicants with CV gaps (maternity leave) and those who'd earned their PhD's more than 10 years prior.   That's the fault of the gov't, not universities.

That the real gap is <10% despite these factors indicates that the environment is far more egalitarian and supportive than the minister claims.

While cleaning up the McKenzie is a valuable service, it may be time to look at septic systems and lawn products used near waterways especially as eutrophication from fertilizers and household products can pollute water and produce algae blooms significantly as temps heat up. 

Re-education is needed for urban dwellers who move to the country with septic systems and who use chlorine, strong dishwasher soap, high nitrogen detergents and other common household products that inhibit septics from operating properly.  People in cities should also reduce or stop using such products. 

Washing clothes with hot water results in river heating, sewage plants cannot cool water adversely affecting fish habitat. Use hot water only when necessary.

Comment: The FBI has already reviewed tens of thousands of e-mails, and hasn't found any criminal activity in them. The reason that Comey's action was illegal is that it allows Trump to smear Clinton with completely unfounded speculation and innuendo days before the election when she isn't able to access the e-mails to defend herself.  It may or may not have been Comey's intention to provide the Trump camp with this blunt but hollow weapon to pummel Clinton with, but it took only milliseconds for the Trump campaign to take it up and wield it, as insubstantial as it is.  This is the whole reason that the Justice department prohibits this type of disclosure in the last weeks of an election.  Comey should have known better.

Comment: Hi, Anon - Here's one reason why I would like Francis to be more clear. As you may know, we lead an intentional faith community. We try to limit our membership to about 40 people because at a certain point, you wind up creating structures and duplicating the very problems we're trying to resolve. So when we get to 40 or so members, we break off a group and start again with a core of ten or fifteen.

That means we're always getting inquiries from potential new members, who often come to us with questions about their churches. As you can imagine, one of the questions we hear frequently is about the church's position on divorce and remarriage. We make every effort to not exploit the church's situation in order to get new members, but therein lies the problem: we don't know what to say is the church's position at the moment, and AL is not as helpful as we'd like. Since we don't want to exploit folks, we have to send them back to clergy we know will help them, but what happens after that?

Comment: "Trump says hacking did not affect U.S. election outcome"

Two, no, three points.

One, the issue is whether or not Russia (versus the 400 lb boy) attempted to interfere in the last US election by getting access to private data and making it public. This, apparently, is true, as Mr Trump's denials are now mute. Two, there is no way that Mr Trump or anyone else can say that this interference was, or was not, effective. Three, by saying that 'hacking did not affect the election outcome' Mr Trump is communicating that he believes (with ample good reason) that the people he expects to be listening are fools.

I get the impression that Mr Trump was under the assumption that 'hacking' was some sort of technical wizardry akin to black magic, and as such could never be 'proven'. His age is a prime indicator. Hacking is dull, boring, and like much on the interwebs, has really low hit rates. And leaves lots of tracks.

Comment: I think he may be talking about illegal pitches, where the trailing foot of a pitcher must remain in contact with the ground until after the ball is released. The umpires rarely watch for this unless an opposing coach complains. Even then, the umps often cannot see it in real time. Some of the "best" pitchers gain a mechanical advantage by leaving the ground before releasing the ball and are simply allowed to do it. Other pitchers get called for it, which awards a base to the batter and all runners. White, having been an elite pitcher, can spot pitchers who leave the ground and often asks the umps to call it. Opposing coaches probably hate him for it. The fact is, the rule exists for a reason, but it is enforced rarely and unevenly, which is bad for the game. White makes a good point.

Comment: I lived for many years in Juneau, which has a 5% sales tax with few exceptions.   I bought gas and oil, groceries, and building materials and such that were impractical to buy Outside.   We bought little or no clothing for ourselves or the kids in Juneau; I don't think I owned a stitch bought there when I left.   We had an account with Alaska Marine Lines so we could take advantage of free shipping offers to Seattle and then only pay the barge rate from SEA to JNU when we bought larger items such as furniture.   If a sales tax is not to do great harm to local retail, at minimum it should be imposed on orders from businesses that have a physical presence in the State and the sales tax should apply on instate orders to all locations in the State.   People adapt and nobody wants to pay taxes that they can avoid.

Comment: Good questions.  Trigger height is the building height at which some adjustment is to occur such as a step back.  Step back is where a building narrows and it looks like a stair step.  Internal property lines occur when there is more than one building on a single property.  The distance from an internal property line provides for light and space between multiple buildings.  Massing studies would be when buildings' impact on one another are assessed for density, aesthetics etc.  I hope this helps.

Comment: This could force another election. The Liberals still have the confidence of the Crown as they are the majority party. Yes the opposition can call for an early non-confidence motion and the LG would have to make a determination whether to go to the polls again or ask the minority NDP to form a government. It appears the NDP/Green collaboration isn't prepared to do this. So, the Liberals can bring forward legislation that will be voted on in a case by case basis. Defeating anything but a money bill isn't a confidence vote and won't trigger an election. Defeating non money bill legislation just because won't cut it with the electorate as it will be viewed as obstructionist (they'll have to have good reasons to defeat it). So, this allows Christy some latitude in crafting legislation and how a budget would be tied to that legislation.

Or she could just go to the LG and say offer the job to the NDP. Then the fun would really start as their new found friendship with the Greens could end.

Comment: It amazes me how often fiscal conservatives will simply revert to first principles - Econ 101, as we say - as a justification for any policy or any particular policy. Sure, "choice" and "competition" are good. But how good? How much choice is optimal? How much competition? And what will we sacrifice for them?
The point about the health care market is *not*, as the author implies, that we think it's "too complicated" for free markets. That's a strawman. 
The point is that free markets do not work to deliver market goods to all people. Free markets are great for setting market prices, and below that price no one gets the services. That's not complex, it's simple: If you want a Canada where your neighbour gets health care even if they're poor or lost their job or unemployed or differently abled, then we do not want and cannot afford a free-market system. 
Talking about the warm fuzzy feelings "choice" and "competition" give you does not address that.

Comment: I have a few ETFs, but they are a small part of my portfolio.  Ditto mutual funds....  Most of my equity holdings are individual shares.  The transaction fees are only trading commissions and, since I‚Äôm a ‚Äòbuy and hold‚Äô investor, the fees are minimal and under my control.  To me, they represent to cost I pay for the full-service broker‚Äôs research dept.  I have no interest in doing detailed company research, so I‚Äôm willing to pay for for that service.  If I opted for mutual funds, lots of ETFs, or a managed portfolio, I‚Äôd pay a lot more in fees!   The use of computer algorithms in ETFs worry me as a potential contributor to/cause of ‚Äòflash crashes‚Äô  so I think they could become a negative factor in the market.  The fundamental problem that gives rise to all the fund-type products is that too many people do not take responsibility to managing their finances!   ETFs seem to be the latest product that allows people to think they are managing their money smartly while actually ignoring it!

Comment: There is a better book available. Our forefathers did the best they could to adapt from it, but 27 times their descendants (our forefathers), worked to correct the deficiencies. And, while we might think Supreme Court interpretations binding, there is higher authority to whom interpretations belong (Gen 40:8).
I don't disagree on the humble servants notion, but "public" is difficult to define and to handle its boundaries.

Comment: Alexandra,
I have long tried to be an "independent," although I will readily admit that in terms of politics, I lean right, while in terms of social justice, I lean a bit to the left.  Those ARE my biases, and I don't think I've ever tried to hide them.  My wife and I have tended to be TV news junkies for a while now, and I HAVE seen a lot of what I will call "screaming."

I don't profess to be a constitutional scholar, but while I law school I DID tend to load up on constitutional law classes.  So I DO find it more than a little amusing to listen to the punditry and commentators talk about the constitution and what it does/does not say.

As to "screaming," all you need to is to tune into the evening news to see it, daily.  My point is that we need to get past that, and back to respectful disagreement in society.    

As to the nuclear option, much ado about nothing.  The "60-vote" threshold is a senate rule, relatively recent at that.  It required civility in Congress to work.

Comment: The problem with the sale of HydroOne is that electricity transmission is one of the rare cases of a "natural monopoly".

People who support free markets support just that, free markets.  That is to say a good or service that multiple companies can freely compete to provide and consumers have a choice to select whichever option they feel provides the best value.  Privatization is not the end goal but rather a means to an end because governments, for whatever reason, tend to refuse to allow free and open competition.  As a result if you want free markets you tend to need privatization.

However a "natural monopoly" is a case where competition really isn't feasible at this time from a purely technological standpoint.  There is just no way for a company to come in and compete with HydroOne, whether they are public or private, even if there were no laws preventing that.

As a result HydroOne is doing nothing to create a free market, it just changes a public monopoly for a private monopoly.

Comment: Firstly, secondary sources are the primary means of accessing this information. Sweeping every police departments files for homicides in every local, county, state and federal jurisdiction is a mockery of research and then decrying anything less as "cherry picked" is laughable.

Second, I am comparing overall homicide rate to those that were perpetrated with firearms, this provides context in how the US is over-represented in gun homicides. I use homicides to avoid accidental deaths and suicides which are different than the topic. 

Finally, the use of per capita rates is not how we measure over time, but an way to view data to account for differences in population. For instance can I compare Palmer to NYC for crime based on number reported? No. I need to use per capita rates to account for likelihood an individual will be impacted, that likelihood is expressed as a number out of 100k.

Comment: I am "first generation Canadian", my parents having been children when they immigrated to Canada.  I'd always thought that "diversity" was a big positive in that it brought a plethora of new ideas to the country, new ways of looking at things.  However, having read this article, and given it some thought, I agree with its author.  My parents embraced all things Canadian and insisted that I not learn their native language (THAT was a mistake!) .  They didn't tolerate their immigrant parents fond remembrances of the life they left (few but fond) and were harsh with them.  Their ethnicity was apparent primarily in their food choices and little else.  Their attitude was that the family had come to Canada to leave behind certain negatives - not bring them to Canada with them.  While I think they might have enriched my life by holding onto more of the "old", I am grateful to have obtained a university education and married late in life - neither of which would have been possible otherwise.

Comment: This statement lacks understanding of how electric (and IC engines work). Electric motors usually generate much more torque at 0 speed than an ICE which requires high rpms to produce sufficient power to overcome its own piston compression requirements (remember each piston is only producing power about 25% of the time, and that power stroke needs to power the remaining compression, injection and exhaust strokes) ergo an ICE engine tends to hit its peak torque towards its mid level revs and then needs a gearbox to convert those ~3000rpms into  1 rpm at the wheel. (Diesels tend to have a torque curve that continues to rise with rpms)  Whereas an electric motor generates instant torque at starting thus no need to reduce rpms to wheels, and the rotating magnetic field eventually brakes the amount of current into the stator magnets thus reducing the torque once the rotor is turning. But ultimately the stall torque load of most electric motors is still higher than peak torque in an ICE.

Comment: "If configured right, when one dies, the other collects the TFSA content and adds the amount to their TFSA."

What Ancientalso is referring to is how you name the person who recieves your TFSA upon your death.  Do not have a person named as a 'beneficiary' as upon your death the TFSA will be cashed out with no further tax sheltering. Name the person (it this case it can only be a spouse or common law spouse) that recieves your TFSA as a 'Successor Holder'.  This will allow them to 'roll over' the TSFA into theirs regardless of the contribution room available and allow the money to continue to grow tax free. 

"The TFSA continues to exist and both its value at the date of the original holder's death and any income earned after that date continue to be sheltered from tax under the new successor holder."

http://www.cra-arc.gc.ca/tx/ndvdls/tpcs/tfsa-celi/dth/sccrhldr-eng.html

Comment: The Charlie Gard situation illustrates the worrisome pitfalls of single-payer government run healthcare. The British NHS (National Health Service) decided baby Charlie's case was hopeless.  Therefore, they would continue medicating him for pain but withdraw further treatment and all attempts at life support. When Charlie's parents objected they found they had no say in the matter and no right to pursue a course of treatment, even at their own cost, that they desired.
Is this what we want for America?  Do we as healthcare consumers want the federal government deciding at what point the lives of our children are hopeless and then to legally beat us into submission if we disagree?  Americans are not Europeans.  We are more individualistic, self-reliant and independent-minded.  We insist on deciding for ourselves what is best for us and our loved ones. Remember little Charlie - if only he had been born in the Land of the Free - at least his parents would have had a voice.

Comment: I imagine few businesses could survive a 55% tax bill increase. It seems like such increases should be done more gradually, at the very least. At the same time, the property in question, a 2-story retail-only building, makes no sense in context of current and desired density of that part of Toronto. Would we want to preserve it if it were a laundromat? A lawyer's office?

Unless the building has heritage value (which I don't think is the case), it probably _should_ be replaced over time by a higher-density building. That doesn't need to mean a 50-story condo tower, but even the surrounding buildings are 6-8 stories. A taller building would obviously be able to split up the property taxes among more tenants.

The property owner should probably sell the property and make a bundle of money. The restaurant itself should probably find a new home in a denser building. If we make special exceptions for everything, though, then the city will be starving itself of its "best use".

Comment: Interesting column. 

I read a column in the last year written by the prominent U.S. statistician Nate Silver (who got the 2012 Presidential Election entirely correct, and missed--like everyone else--the 2016 election). He did a study on wages and found the one group over the last number of years that has had strong wage growth are those that work long hours. 

I had a few jobs like that and in some cases I found myself on a project that simply demanded those hours. In other cases, the company routinely expected those hours week-in, week-out. 

So does everyone want to work 50-60 hrs a week? Well no. Some of us want to have a life outside of work. The places that wanted an extra day or so of work every week, I left. 

Sorry. Didn't want to do that, folks. 

And yes, btw, there are some 'males' who work these hours because, even today, there is an unconscious bias in society that still looks to the 'male' to ultimately provide for his family, come Hell or high water.

Comment: The Resturant industry has always fought for tip credit. It allows them to pay wages BELOW the minimum wage by counting an employees tips to satisfy the employer's obligation to pay the minimum wage. The employers often choose to employ workers less than the minimum hours to qualify for benefits and as parttime workers, they need the tips to get by. The reality is that workers who work lunch shifts or breakfast shifts do not get the high tip income. The reality is that nearly ALL these workers are not unionized and are subject to the employer's arbitrary assignment of hours...and number of hours...Most are also expected to share their tips with busboys, etc. . The reality is that employer violations of wage and hour laws in the resturant industry is among the highest of any industry in Oregon. That SOME fancier resturants have SOME waiters or waitresses in Portland  may  earn a higher wage hides the reality that MOST do not, especially outside of Portland's trendier spots.

Comment: In the right patient at the right time, yes.   However, from what I`ve read, that accounts for fewer than 10% of all prescriptions in the case of statins in general and with the growing expertise in genetics, it should be possible more than ever to identify those with the best chance of benefitting and those who will see no benefit and may see harm from taking them.

In the case I know best, the ACE inhibitor (Ramipril) was invaluable.   Zocor and Lipitor (statins) caused a lot of grief (lots of unpleasant side effects) and the patient eventually got the cardiologist to agree to drop the statin.   Based on tests done later, it was clear the statin had likely been of negligible, if any, value, and the ACE inhibitor plus very low dose blood thinner had been doing the heavy lifting.   In the end, what started as a five drug regime was reduce to two.   It made a big difference for the patient and their ability to live life pleasantly and also represented a significant difference in cost.
